natural problem:
What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$
natural solution: \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "m * x + b = y"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. lim (\<lambda>x. P x - m * x - b) x = 0"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "m * x + b = y"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. lim (\<lambda>x. P x - m * x - b) x = 0"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a function $P(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$ and a linear equation $y = mx + b$. If the limit of the difference between $P(x)$ and $mx + b$ as $x$ approaches infinity is 0, find the values of $m$ and $b$. The final answer is $m = 1$ and $b = 2$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x^2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x - g x \<rightarrow> 0 as x \<rightarrow> \<infinity>"
shows  "y = x + 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x^2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x - g x \<rightarrow> 0 as x \<rightarrow> \<infinity>"
shows  "y = x + 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two functions, $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$ and $g(x) = x + 2$, find the value of $y$ such that the difference $f(x) - g(x)$ approaches $0$ as $x$ approaches infinity. The final answer is $y = x + 2$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = m * x + b"
and h2 : "m = 1"
and h3 : "b = 2"
shows  "g x = f x as x approaches infinity"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = m * x + b"
and h2 : "m = 1"
and h3 : "b = 2"
shows  "g x = f x as x approaches infinity"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For the function $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$ and the linear function $g(x) = x + 2$, determine if $g(x) = f(x)$ as $x$ approaches infinity.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the slope $m$ and the y-intercept $b$ of the line that can be written in the form $y = mx + b$, given that $y$ is also equal to the function $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$. The final answer is that the slope $m = 1$ and the y-intercept $b = 2$.

fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "y = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"

theorem
fixes x y :: real

 ### Proof

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "\<exists> m b. m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "\<exists> m b. m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: The problem is defined by a function $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$. Find the slope $m$ and y-intercept $b$ of a line $y = mx + b$ such that $m = 1$ and $b = 2$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x - Q x = R x"
shows  "y = x + 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x - Q x = R x"
shows  "y = x + 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = \frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$, $Q(x) = x$, and $R(x) = 2$, find $y$ such that $P(x) - Q(x) = R(x)$ for all $x$. The final answer is $y = x + 2$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. Q x \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x / Q x = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1" "b = 2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. Q x \<noteq> 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x / Q x = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1" "b = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = 2x^2 + 7x + 10$ and $Q(x) = 2x + 3$ (with $Q(x) \neq 0$), find the slope $m$ and the y-intercept $b$ of the line that passes through the points where $y = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$. The final answer is $m = 1$ and $b = 2$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real
assumes h0 : "y = m * x + b"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. y x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+2
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +2 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x+3 & 2x^2&+7x&+10 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & +3x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 4x &  +10 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 4x &  +6 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &  4 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+7x+10}{2x+3} = x + 2 + \frac{4}{2x+3}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real
assumes h0 : "y = m * x + b"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. y x = (2 * x powr 2 + 7 * x + 10) / (2 * x + 3)"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given the equation of a line in the form $y = mx + b$ where $y$ is equal to $\frac{2x^2 + 7x + 10}{2x + 3}$ for all $x$, find the values of $m$ and $b$. The final answer is $m = 1$ and $b = 2$.
